Notes: The learned word rótula ('kneecap' in both Sp. and Port.) is from the same root as Spanish rodilla. Sp. de hinojos 'kneeling' is from the same source as Port. joelho.

Spanish: carretera < carreta + ‑era < carro < Lat. {{sm|carrus}} < Gaulish carros

Portuguese: alimentação biológica, Bio < Lat. + Greek {{sm|alere + βίος+λογία}}
Notes: In Brazil, the most common expression is the same as in Spanish, albeit written with an â instead of an á: comida orgânica.
Spanish also has cuero. Portuguese pele usually means 'skin' or 'fur', but it can also mean 'leather'.

Spanish: comisaría (de policía) < Lat. + Gr. {{sm|comissarius + politia < πολιτεία }}
Portuguese: esquadra, posto de polícia < Lat. + Gr. {{sm|ex-quadrata, positus + politia < πολιτεία}}
Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use 'delegacia (de polícia)'

Portuguese: furadeira (Brazilian Portuguese) < Lat. {{sm|forare + eira}} or berbequim (European Portuguese) < Fr. {{sm|vilebrequin}} < Dutch {{sm|wimmelkijn}}
árvore de cames < Lat. + Germanic {{sm|arbōs + kamm}}

Notes: In zoology, Port. also uses brânquias (branchiae).

Portuguese: frango < Probably Fr. francolin < Ita. francolino, all of {{sm|uncertain origin|}}

Notes: Portuguese lâmpada usually means 'light bulb' (except in certain idioms, like lâmpada de Aladino, i.e., 'Aladdin's lamp')

Portuguese: coruja (*maybe from Lat. cunicularis) of {{sm|uncertain origin|}}

Spanish: perrera < uncertain origin, perhaps Pre-Roman. {{sm|perro + era}}

Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use térreo
Span. also has prisión and Port. archaic cárcere.

Spanish: zaquizamí,[7] buhardilla < Hisp-Ar. {{sm| سقف في السماء (saqf fassamā)}}, < Lat. {{sm|bufus < buharda}}
Portuguese: água-furtada, mansarda < Lat. {{sm|aquam + furtus}}, < Fr. {{sm|mansarde < François Mansart (architect)}}
sala de operações, sala de cirurgia, bloco operatório < Ger + Lat. {{sm|sal + operatio}}, < Ger + Gr. {{sm|sal + χειρουργική}}, < Ger + Lat. {{sm|bluk(k)an + operatio}}

Spanish: investigación con células madre < Lat. {{sm|vestigium + cum + cellula + mater}}
Portuguese: pesquisa de células estaminais < Lat. {{sm|perquirere + de + cellula + staminis}}
vaga < Gothic {{sm|vega}}[10] or < Old Norse {{sm|vágr}},[11] both from Ancient Germanic 'vigan' to shake
vassoura, giesta, carqueja < Lat. {{sm|verrere}}, < Lat. {{sm|genista}}, < Maybe Lat. {{sm|quercus}}

Spanish: en otro lugar < Lat. {{sm|in alter localis}}, en alguna parte < Lat. {{sm|in aliquis unos pars}}, en ningún lugar < Lat. {{sm|in nec unus localis}}
Portuguese: alhures < Provençal {{sm|alhors}}, algures < Lat. + Provençal {{sm|aliquod + hors}}, nenhures < Lat. + Provençal {{sm| nec + hors}}
relvado, grama < Lat. relevare, < Lat. gramen

Spanish: tarjeta < Fr. targe + diminutive suffix eta
Portuguese: cartão, carta < Gr. χάρτης < Lat. charta

Spanish: maletero < Old Fr. + Sp. suffix malle + eta + ero
guantero < Frankish + Sp. suffix want + ero

Notes: Sp. magro means 'lean', in reference to meat

Spanish: fruto de la pasión < Lat. fructa + passio

Notes: Lat. {{sm|ventānam}} 'wind opening' < {{sm|ventus}} 'wind'. Lat. {{sm|iānuella}} is a diminutive of {{sm|iānua}} 'door, opening' (the same root as Eng. January and janitor) < the name {{sm|ianus}}, the God of gates or doors.

Meaning: to disrupt, to get in the way (of someone/smthg)

Notes: Port. borrar means 'to smudge'; cf. Sp. borroso 'blurry'. Sp. apagar means 'to turn off' (a meaning that also exists in Port., e.g. apagar a luz 'to turn off the light').
Olvidar also exists in Port. (but is far less common). A learned cognate, obliterar, exists in both languages.
Port. colheita and recolha (both < Lat. {{sm|collecta}}) generally refer to the harvest of crops, wine or data collection (i.e. online surveys, personal data).

Port. also has negro and Sp. also has prieto. Use and connotation vary greatly (i.e. the use of preto to refer to people of African descent is considered a slur in Port. but the prieto in Sp. can often mean dark"
column6: or "swarthy" in a similar fashion to moreno in both Sp. and Port.)."

Portuguese: cabeleireiro < cabeleira 'head of hair; wig' < cabelo < Lat. {{sm|capillus}}

Notes: Brazilian Port. tends to use xícara < Sp. jícara < Nahuatl xīcalli.

Portuguese: garfo < either via Lat. {{sm|graphium}} or < Fr. {{sm|greffe}}

Notes: Both Port. and Sp. have 'toxicomania' for drug addiction

Portuguese: orçamento < Uncertain, Ita. 'orza' or likely Frankish *lurz + Lat. {{sm|orça[12] + mentum}}
